snippet: A new survey finds that those without a college degree have dismal job prospects and considerable obstacles blocking improvement.
abstract: Report from the John J Heldrick Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University finds that young Americans without a college degree face dismal job prospects and considerable roadblocks to improvement; just 37 percent of Americans who graduated high school in the period from 2006-2008 are employed full time, with another 23 percent in part time positions; only 16 percent of the classes of 2009-2011 have full-time jobs; most say they need more education, but are unable to take steps to achieve further schooling.
lead_paragraph: A new survey finds that those without a college degree have dismal job prospects and considerable obstacles blocking improvement.

headline.seo: More Young Americans Out of High School Are Also Out of Work
headline.main: More Young Americans Out of High School Are Also Out of Work
headline.print_headline: More Young Americans Out of High School Are Also Out of Work
